description: The Systems Security Certified Practitioner (SSCP) certification is one of the leading certifications from (ISC)2. This is a certification for hands on practitioners with the responsibility of making sure IT security concerns are addressed in an enterprise environment and is designed for IT security professionals with one or more years of field experience who are seeking to advance their career by validating their knowledge and experience. If IT security is your preferred career path, then the SSCP is a great starting point for you.
name: Systems Security Certified Practitioner
subtitle: SSCP

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don introduce the viewers to the (ISC)2 SSCP certification. They discuss the requirements to becoming SSCP certified as well as the general topic areas covered by the certification.
episodes.title: Overview of SSCP
episodes.transcript:
1

[SOUND] Welcome back to ITProTV.

2

3

with us is Mr Adam Gordon.

we want to take a minute to

11

Who it's a good fit for, and
how you go about obtaining it

12

13

16

>> Absolutely, so the ideas behind
the SSCP, the system security certified

17
00:00:53,350 --> 00:00:58,350
practitioner by the way, that's what SSCP
stands for, an (ISC)2 certification.

18
00:00:58,350 --> 00:01:01,050
A certification for
a hands on practitioner, so

19
00:01:01,050 --> 00:01:05,540
much more so than somebody who is
going to be a more senior manager.

20
00:01:05,540 --> 00:01:09,729
This is a person who is gonna have hands
on day to day responsibility for making

21
00:01:09,729 --> 00:01:14,314
sure that IT, specifically IT security
concerns in the enterprise are addressed.

22
00:01:14,314 --> 00:01:18,337
So, they'll be the people that will be
in the trenches dealing with firewalls,

23
00:01:18,337 --> 00:01:22,954
dealing with networks, setting up wireless
security, setting up virtualized security,

24
00:01:22,954 --> 00:01:24,687
and doing that on a regular basis.

25
00:01:24,687 --> 00:01:28,221
And so, we typically see somebody
with a year of experience going

26
00:01:28,221 --> 00:01:30,460
through certification like this.

27
00:01:30,460 --> 00:01:35,560
Some hands on real world experience along
with some theory behind some of the areas

28
00:01:35,560 --> 00:01:38,940
that are gonna be covered in the common
body of knowledge, what we call the CBK.

29
00:01:38,940 --> 00:01:40,129
Which is the reference point for this.

30
00:01:40,129 --> 00:01:44,350
And you really got to be, if you're out
there thinking about becoming an SSCP,

31
00:01:44,350 --> 00:01:47,690
be looking to market your skills
to your potential employers.

32
00:01:47,690 --> 00:01:52,185
By saying this is a credential that
validates me being able to do these things

33
00:01:52,185 --> 00:01:54,990
real-time as I go into the environment.

34
00:01:54,990 --> 00:01:57,198
And I'm gonna be able to
help you setup your network,

35
00:01:57,198 --> 00:02:00,740
will be able to help you secure it,
help you monitor it, but

36
00:02:00,740 --> 00:02:03,930
also help you to understand
what goes on in a day to day.

37
00:02:03,930 --> 00:02:05,410
>> Yeah, and that's a really good point.

38
00:02:05,410 --> 00:02:10,700
The SSCP, you'll hear it described a lot
of times in conjunction with this CISSP,

39
00:02:10,700 --> 00:02:12,960
which is another
certification from (ISC)2.

40
00:02:12,960 --> 00:02:17,050
The CISSP very highly
regarded certification, but

41
00:02:17,050 --> 00:02:20,002
it is focused more around
that security manager.

42
00:02:20,002 --> 00:02:23,300
That high-level knowledge, that
a person who's been in the trenches for

43
00:02:23,300 --> 00:02:24,960
a long time.

44
00:02:24,960 --> 00:02:27,410
The SSCP, that's more of the doer,

45
00:02:27,410 --> 00:02:29,830
the person who's actually
getting their hands dirty.

46
00:02:29,830 --> 00:02:32,640
Getting these systems put in place,
protecting the network, so

47
00:02:32,640 --> 00:02:33,470
it's really cool.

48
00:02:33,470 --> 00:02:35,650
It covers a lot of neat technologies.

49
00:02:35,650 --> 00:02:38,370
Adam, what are some of the things
that we cover in SSCP?

50
00:02:38,370 --> 00:02:41,891
>> So, the criteria that we're gonna look
at are what we call the common body of

51
00:02:41,891 --> 00:02:42,782
knowledge areas.

52
00:02:42,782 --> 00:02:45,448
There are seven of them,
are gonna be access control.

53
00:02:45,448 --> 00:02:48,720
So we're gonna be talking about all
the things associated with how we control

54
00:02:48,720 --> 00:02:49,560
access.

55
00:02:49,560 --> 00:02:53,030
The policies, the standards, the
implementation models, things like that.

56
00:02:53,030 --> 00:02:55,990
We'll take a look at security operations,
and administration.

57
00:02:55,990 --> 00:02:58,828
So we'll be talking about what
a security administrator does,

58
00:02:58,828 --> 00:03:01,506
what are the kind of things that
add to management policies,

59
00:03:01,506 --> 00:03:03,780
things of that nature that
you might be looking at.

60
00:03:03,780 --> 00:03:06,195
We'll take a look at monitoring,
and analysis.

61
00:03:06,195 --> 00:03:11,670
And talk about continuous monitoring,
how we monitor, how we look at results.

62
00:03:11,670 --> 00:03:16,460
Things such as firewall logs,
intrusion protection, and defense systems,

63
00:03:16,460 --> 00:03:17,610
things of that nature.

64
00:03:17,610 --> 00:03:20,690
We'll be taking a look at risk response,
and recovery.

65
00:03:20,690 --> 00:03:22,280
So, what is risk management?

66
00:03:22,280 --> 00:03:24,310
How important is risk,
threat, vulnerability?

67
00:03:24,310 --> 00:03:25,340
How do we address those?

68
00:03:25,340 --> 00:03:26,580
How do we define them?

69
00:03:26,580 --> 00:03:28,800
What is business continuity?

70
00:03:28,800 --> 00:03:30,290
What is disaster recovery?

71
00:03:30,290 --> 00:03:34,080
How do we plan for those events that may,
or may not be on the horizon for

72
00:03:34,080 --> 00:03:37,340
us initially as we open
up our minds to security.

73
00:03:37,340 --> 00:03:41,290
But ultimately as we know, when we
are security management professionals, and

74
00:03:41,290 --> 00:03:44,240
security practitioners,
we have to address risk every day.

75
00:03:44,240 --> 00:03:45,610
And so, how do we do that?

76
00:03:45,610 --> 00:03:49,069
Cryptography, and the use of cryptography
in networks to provide security.

77
00:03:49,069 --> 00:03:52,530
[INAUDIBLE] Have been a lot of talk
over the last couple of years about what

78
00:03:52,530 --> 00:03:56,565
security is, and is not, based on being
able to look at people's email, or listen

79
00:03:56,565 --> 00:04:00,339
to their phone calls, all sorts of things
that we may, or may not be aware of.

80
00:04:00,339 --> 00:04:01,064
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

81
00:04:01,064 --> 00:04:03,691
the security practitioner
takes a look at that, and

82
00:04:03,691 --> 00:04:06,737
from the practitioner perspective
would say to a business,

83
00:04:06,737 --> 00:04:10,310
this is what we need to do in order
to implement a secure solution.

84
00:04:10,310 --> 00:04:12,210
These are the kind of
algorithms we may use, and

85
00:04:12,210 --> 00:04:15,900
these are the kind of cryptographic
solutions we may wanna put in place.

86
00:04:15,900 --> 00:04:18,950
These are the secure protocols
that we want to use.

87
00:04:18,950 --> 00:04:22,990
For networks, and communication,
we take a look at the bread, and

88
00:04:22,990 --> 00:04:25,660
butter of what a security
practitioner does everyday.

89
00:04:25,660 --> 00:04:29,260
We think about the networks,
the telecommunications solutions that they

90
00:04:29,260 --> 00:04:31,720
deploy, whether they're wireless,
or wired.

91
00:04:31,720 --> 00:04:35,297
Whether they are looking at remote access,
or people that work in an office,

92
00:04:35,297 --> 00:04:39,041
they're going to look at firewalls,
wireless technology, all the things that

93
00:04:39,041 --> 00:04:42,804
are associated with network access,
really top to bottom, across that stack.

94
00:04:42,804 --> 00:04:47,499
And then we finish up with malicious code,
and activity, one of my most

95
00:04:47,499 --> 00:04:52,290
favorite sections in the sense that I
do a lot of work around these areas.

96
00:04:52,290 --> 00:04:55,975
Is to spend time talking about the things
that can go wrong in a system, And

97
00:04:55,975 --> 00:04:58,870
understand how to identify them,
and be aware of them.

98
00:04:58,870 --> 00:05:03,260
So that way we are able to zero in on the
issues we have, and as a result hopefully,

99
00:05:03,260 --> 00:05:08,210
identify the problems with malware,
trojans, worms, anything that could go

100
00:05:08,210 --> 00:05:12,690
on with, not only transmissions of those,
but countermeasures associated with them.

101
00:05:12,690 --> 00:05:14,250
>> So, those are our seven domains.

102
00:05:14,250 --> 00:05:16,500
These are the knowledge areas
that we need to focus in,

103
00:05:16,500 --> 00:05:20,028
if we plan on getting
the SSCP certification.

104
00:05:20,028 --> 00:05:23,090
So Adam, and let's say that I look at
that list, and I say, you know what,

105
00:05:23,090 --> 00:05:24,320
I'm an expert on all of that stuff.

106
00:05:24,320 --> 00:05:25,760
I'm ready to take the exam today.

107
00:05:25,760 --> 00:05:28,030
So, what do I need to know about the exam?

108
00:05:28,030 --> 00:05:30,940
>> So
the exam is gonna be computer-based today.

109
00:05:30,940 --> 00:05:35,631
Years ago, if you were sitting for an exam
from (ISC)2, they were paper-based exams.

110
00:05:35,631 --> 00:05:38,760
They were going to use a scantron bubble,
and answer sheet, and

111
00:05:38,760 --> 00:05:42,190
you would sit for four hours for this,
or three hours for this exam rather.

112
00:05:42,190 --> 00:05:45,850
And it would have been 125 questions, and
you would have had to go through, and

113
00:05:45,850 --> 00:05:47,310
write out all the answers by hand.

114
00:05:47,310 --> 00:05:48,850
Today, they're computerized.

115
00:05:48,850 --> 00:05:52,085
You can go into a secure testing center,
and you can take the exam.

116
00:05:52,085 --> 00:05:56,612
It is still 125 questions, you need to
score 700, or better in order to pass.

117
00:05:56,612 --> 00:06:00,737
And you will need to make sure you have
at least one year of proven experience in

118
00:06:00,737 --> 00:06:04,555
the field in one, or more of the seven
areas we just identified for you.

119
00:06:04,555 --> 00:06:08,813
That you can document on your application,
and then you're able to validate that

120
00:06:08,813 --> 00:06:13,005
experience through the application
process after you take the exam.

121
00:06:13,005 --> 00:06:15,975
And so, what happens is,
you go, and sit for the exam.

122
00:06:15,975 --> 00:06:17,185
Pass the exam.

123
00:06:17,185 --> 00:06:20,115
Then you go through an application
process through (ISC)2,

124
00:06:20,115 --> 00:06:21,607
where you submit an application.

125
00:06:21,607 --> 00:06:26,200
Validate your three-year resume, and your
credentials that you have the experience.

126
00:06:26,200 --> 00:06:27,350
And then you're able to,

127
00:06:27,350 --> 00:06:31,070
along with the fee that you pay to apply,
send all that paperwork into (ISC)2.

128
00:06:31,070 --> 00:06:34,470
There's a small delay,
while they go through the application.

129
00:06:34,470 --> 00:06:37,350
You may randomly,
be chosen to have an application audited.

130
00:06:37,350 --> 00:06:40,470
If you are, you may be asked some
follow up questions about 10%

131
00:06:40,470 --> 00:06:43,040
of people on average get audited randomly.

132
00:06:43,040 --> 00:06:46,320
But more often than not, you simply
go through the application process.

133
00:06:46,320 --> 00:06:49,260
Within about a week, give, or
take depending on the time of the year,

134
00:06:49,260 --> 00:06:53,280
you hear back that you've been accepted
as long as your credentials hold up, and

135
00:06:53,280 --> 00:06:55,170
everything is validated on your resume.

136
00:06:55,170 --> 00:06:58,310
And your granted in this
case the SSCP credential.

137
00:06:58,310 --> 00:07:00,030
Once your granted that credential,

138
00:07:00,030 --> 00:07:03,530
you will have a three-year cycle where
you are expected as a professional

139
00:07:03,530 --> 00:07:07,890
in the field practicing your
craft to accrue CPE credits.

140
00:07:07,890 --> 00:07:11,720
You must do 40 credits a year in order to
be able to maintain your certification,

141
00:07:11,720 --> 00:07:14,430
120 credits over a three-year cycle.

142
00:07:14,430 --> 00:07:17,970
You are then able to provide
documentation about those credits through

143
00:07:17,970 --> 00:07:19,890
an online portal, through the web.

144
00:07:19,890 --> 00:07:22,610
You submit them, and
then you pay your membership fees, and

145
00:07:22,610 --> 00:07:26,720
renew your certification on
a three-year cycle based on those fees.

146
00:07:26,720 --> 00:07:31,340
Assuming you stay active, and you get
your CPEs, there is no re-certification

147
00:07:31,340 --> 00:07:35,390
process at this point,
meaning you don't have to re-sir the exam.

148
00:07:35,390 --> 00:07:39,160
However, if you let your certification
lapse, if you don't stay active, you will

149
00:07:39,160 --> 00:07:42,570
need to re-sit the exam, so it's really
a question of what you choose to do.

150
00:07:42,570 --> 00:07:45,950
But there are professionals out there that
just simply want to re-certify every three

151
00:07:45,950 --> 00:07:48,605
years, because they wanna prove they're
staying current on the technology,

152
00:07:48,605 --> 00:07:50,015
and up to date with the knowledge.

153
00:07:50,015 --> 00:07:52,275
So, truly up to you at the end of the day.

154
00:07:52,275 --> 00:07:54,284
>> Yeah, one thing I like to
highlight about this, (ISC)2,

155
00:07:54,284 --> 00:07:57,135
that they really stress having experience.

156
00:07:57,135 --> 00:07:59,415
And Adam said it for the SSCP,

157
00:07:59,415 --> 00:08:05,145
you're really supposed to have the either
one-year of actual in field experience.

158
00:08:05,145 --> 00:08:07,900
Or sometimes you hear
people say the equivalency.

159
00:08:07,900 --> 00:08:11,510
Well, when you submit your
paperwork to the (ISC)2,

160
00:08:11,510 --> 00:08:14,300
you show that you have to have
documented one-year of experience.

161
00:08:14,300 --> 00:08:16,210
Its not like CompTIA, or
where it can be equivalent.

162
00:08:16,210 --> 00:08:18,580
You actually need to have that experience.

163
00:08:18,580 --> 00:08:20,140
So, this is a certification
that is designed for

164
00:08:20,140 --> 00:08:23,240
people that are already working
in the security field, or

165
00:08:23,240 --> 00:08:27,200
at least working with security
related infrastructure, and equipment.

166
00:08:27,200 --> 00:08:27,930
What if you don't?

167
00:08:27,930 --> 00:08:29,590
If you're one of those
people that doesn't?

168
00:08:29,590 --> 00:08:33,520
If you're just getting started, and you've
decided that security is the way to go,

169
00:08:33,520 --> 00:08:37,020
then SSCP is probably not
the certification for you right now.

170
00:08:37,020 --> 00:08:41,170
Instead you should be looking to
things like CompTIA Security Plus.

171
00:08:41,170 --> 00:08:44,480
With Security Plus you get the base
knowledge, it's actually a very similar,

172
00:08:44,480 --> 00:08:48,540
not as in depth, but
very similar to what we see here in SSCP.

173
00:08:48,540 --> 00:08:50,550
But it is designed for
people who maybe just starting out,

174
00:08:50,550 --> 00:08:53,520
who may not have any field experience.

175
00:08:53,520 --> 00:08:55,800
But if you're already working the field,
and you're looking for

176
00:08:55,800 --> 00:08:59,910
a way to validate that knowledge
SSCP is the certification to use.

177
00:08:59,910 --> 00:09:02,000
That's one thing I've
always like about (ISC)2,

178
00:09:02,000 --> 00:09:04,370
let's pull up these requirements again.

179
00:09:04,370 --> 00:09:09,280
It is you'll notice how they say,
obtain the required experience, and

180
00:09:09,280 --> 00:09:13,990
then in your study for exam used
these optional educational tools.

181
00:09:13,990 --> 00:09:17,770
In other words, if you have all the field
experience, you don't need study tools.

182
00:09:17,770 --> 00:09:19,080
You can just go, and take the exam.

183
00:09:19,080 --> 00:09:21,680
Go ahead, and have it.

184
00:09:21,680 --> 00:09:24,640
But if you work in it, but
not in all the areas, and you wanna

185
00:09:24,640 --> 00:09:28,215
round off that information, that's where
things like our show come in handy.

186
00:09:28,215 --> 00:09:32,395
The official training, the textbooks,
the self-paced stuff that's out there.

187
00:09:32,395 --> 00:09:35,605
All those different things help to make
sure you've got that base of knowledge to

188
00:09:35,605 --> 00:09:38,275
be ready, for what's on the exam.

189
00:09:38,275 --> 00:09:40,025
>> One other thing we wanna
make sure you're aware of,

190
00:09:40,025 --> 00:09:42,900
as well when you go through
the endorsement process,

191
00:09:42,900 --> 00:09:47,300
this idea of after you actually pass
the exam, the application process.

192
00:09:47,300 --> 00:09:49,520
We call it formally,
the endorsement process.

193
00:09:49,520 --> 00:09:52,150
You have a nine-month window,
(ISC)2 gives you time,

194
00:09:52,150 --> 00:09:55,330
in other words, after you pass the exam,
in order to apply.

195
00:09:55,330 --> 00:09:57,458
So, while you wanna do
it as soon as possible,

196
00:09:57,458 --> 00:10:00,680
we understand that there are needs
to be a window where things happen,

197
00:10:00,680 --> 00:10:02,940
you're busy with work, or whatever.

198
00:10:02,940 --> 00:10:05,638
And so, you're given a window where
you then, those scores are good.

199
00:10:05,638 --> 00:10:07,895
But they're good for
up to nine months for you to apply.

200
00:10:07,895 --> 00:10:10,383
You don't wanna wait too long,
but you can go out, and

201
00:10:10,383 --> 00:10:13,525
get your paperwork in order to get
somebody to formally endorse you,

202
00:10:13,525 --> 00:10:16,420
make sure you have the credential
information in your resume.

203
00:10:16,420 --> 00:10:19,480
You need to validate your experience,
things of that nature.

204
00:10:19,480 --> 00:10:20,630
So, there is a window.

205
00:10:20,630 --> 00:10:24,050
It's not an immediate requirement,
but it is one you wanna be aware of.

206
00:10:24,050 --> 00:10:28,630
And you do have the ability,
try get somebody in your business, or

207
00:10:28,630 --> 00:10:31,560
a peer, or colleague that you know,
to do an endorsement for you.

208
00:10:31,560 --> 00:10:35,190
If they can speak to your experience,
or if there's a sitting SSCP in good

209
00:10:35,190 --> 00:10:38,690
standing, meaning somebody who's already
certified, they can vouch for you,

210
00:10:38,690 --> 00:10:39,530
on your application.

211
00:10:39,530 --> 00:10:42,509
In effect, they do what's called an
endorsement, and they can simply sign off

212
00:10:42,509 --> 00:10:45,543
on the application saying they've known
you, they know the kind of work you do.

213
00:10:45,543 --> 00:10:48,665
And they are familiar with you,
and are willing to stand up for

214
00:10:48,665 --> 00:10:52,100
you if asked, to validate that you
should be able to become an SSCP.

215
00:10:52,100 --> 00:10:56,439
And by doing that, you then are able to
validate the requirements we have listed

216
00:10:56,439 --> 00:11:01,100
for you rather, in terms of making sure
that you can validate your experience.

217
00:11:01,100 --> 00:11:04,510
You also will be required to subscribe
to the (ISC)2 Code of Ethics.

>> I'm frantically clicking

26

But our first objective is
going to be access controls and

28
00:01:41,140 --> 00:01:43,258
is not what I'm displaying on the screen.

29

[LAUGH] It's gonna be access controls and

30

what they are, what they do and

31

>> Absolutely.

32
00:01:52,480 --> 00:01:53,590
Let's talk a bit about that.

33
00:01:53,590 --> 00:01:56,490
And let's start by defining
what access controls are.

34
00:01:56,490 --> 00:02:00,660
The idea in the section that we're
gonna go through with you is how do we,

35
00:02:00,660 --> 00:02:03,870
as security practitioners, how do you,
as security practitioners,

36
00:02:03,870 --> 00:02:07,960
understand how to look at information,and
understand who is accessing it,

37
00:02:07,960 --> 00:02:11,760
who has the rights to access, but
also who doesn't belong accessing it.

38
00:02:11,760 --> 00:02:14,350
And the idea of access control
is much like having a door

39
00:02:14,350 --> 00:02:16,230
as you walk into a room right?

40
00:02:16,230 --> 00:02:20,290
If the door is open, you could potentially
walk through the door, see what's inside.

41
00:02:20,290 --> 00:02:24,620
You may walk by the door, and look in
even though the door is not necessarily

42
00:02:24,620 --> 00:02:28,400
blocking you from being able to enter the
room but you may be able to see inside.

43
00:02:28,400 --> 00:02:31,000
But you may not be able to see everything
inside because maybe there are areas of

44
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:33,660
the room that are not available
to you just by walking by.

45
00:02:33,660 --> 00:02:36,150
You have to fully walk
into the room to see them.

46
00:02:36,150 --> 00:02:40,430
So the idea access control is how
far do we get with information,

47
00:02:40,430 --> 00:02:45,200
what kind of requirements do we have for
authentication, authorization?

48
00:02:45,200 --> 00:02:46,140
Who is the subject?

49
00:02:46,140 --> 00:02:46,960
What is an object?

50
00:02:46,960 --> 00:02:49,150
We will talk, or what is the subject,
what is an object?

51
00:02:49,150 --> 00:02:51,950
We will talk about these things
as well and define these terms.

52
00:02:51,950 --> 00:02:55,873
But the goal is really to understand
how to allow only authorized users,

53
00:02:55,873 --> 00:02:59,923
programs or processes, whatever they are,
whatever we think of them as,

54
00:02:59,923 --> 00:03:03,845
to access information in ways that
we can control, we can document, and

55
00:03:03,845 --> 00:03:07,960
we monitor and understand, both in real
time, and over time archivally and

56
00:03:07,960 --> 00:03:11,095
realistically, going back and
looking historically.

57
00:03:11,095 --> 00:03:13,757
And what are those operations,
what are those management procedures, and

58
00:03:13,757 --> 00:03:16,730
what are those policies, those
are the things we want to talk about.

59
00:03:16,730 --> 00:03:21,130
>> Yeah, and access controls they're one
of those things we use, all the time and

60
00:03:21,130 --> 00:03:24,740
the analogy I know I've used in other
shows is like the locks on the front

61
00:03:24,740 --> 00:03:25,310
of your house.

62
00:03:25,310 --> 00:03:28,000
When I leave the house in the morning,
I lock the door.

63
00:03:28,000 --> 00:03:29,830
That's an access control to my home.

64
00:03:29,830 --> 00:03:32,410
Now that's a physical access control and

65
00:03:32,410 --> 00:03:34,970
we need to focus a little
more on logical because.

66
00:03:34,970 --> 00:03:38,480
In IT, there's only so
much physical equipment we deal with.

67
00:03:38,480 --> 00:03:41,670
Most of the things are logical services
we're providing to our customers and

68
00:03:41,670 --> 00:03:44,560
so that's where we end
up narrowing our focus.

69
00:03:44,560 --> 00:03:47,270
We don't wanna ignore
the physical access controls but

70
00:03:47,270 --> 00:03:48,940
the logical ones become more important.

71
00:03:48,940 --> 00:03:51,330
>> Absolutely, and as Don pointed out,
we wanna have a balance of both,

72
00:03:51,330 --> 00:03:54,780
we wanna make sure we have a good
representation of both elements there.

73
00:03:54,780 --> 00:03:56,380
So, let's talk about some
of the building blocks.

74
00:03:56,380 --> 00:03:57,760
What are those things?

75
00:03:57,760 --> 00:04:00,430
I mentioned subjects and
objects just a moment ago.

76
00:04:00,430 --> 00:04:03,830
A subject is any entity,
any thing that requires or

77
00:04:03,830 --> 00:04:06,540
needs a permission in
order to access an object.

78
00:04:06,540 --> 00:04:10,890
And an object is defined as the goal of
that access but ultimately it is data.

79
00:04:10,890 --> 00:04:15,050
And if we think about, just very generic
user terms that we're very familiar with.

80
00:04:15,050 --> 00:04:17,910
A subject is referred to
typically as a user, or

81
00:04:17,910 --> 00:04:21,310
a process, something that is
looking to access information.

82
00:04:21,310 --> 00:04:23,830
And an object is that information,

83
00:04:23,830 --> 00:04:27,420
typically data in this case more often
than not that we're looking to access.

84
00:04:27,420 --> 00:04:29,780
And then we talk about
things like authentication,

85
00:04:29,780 --> 00:04:33,910
the idea of being able to claim who
you are and really show, who you

86
00:04:33,910 --> 00:04:38,690
are through the process of providing or
proving your identity in some way.

87
00:04:38,690 --> 00:04:41,960
So verification, validation,
proof of identity.

88
00:04:41,960 --> 00:04:45,130
This could be something like a username
being provided when you log on,

89
00:04:45,130 --> 00:04:48,170
it could be a pin, or
some sort of an access code typed

90
00:04:48,170 --> 00:04:51,560
into a system to enable you to
be able to access information.

91
00:04:51,560 --> 00:04:54,630
Identity, specifically identification,

92
00:04:54,630 --> 00:04:58,340
is the idea of being able to claim your
identity to gain access to that resource.

93
00:04:58,340 --> 00:05:04,660
And we talk about this idea of subjects
being able to authorize and then access.

94
00:05:04,660 --> 00:05:07,760
And so the idea is that a subject, a user,

95
00:05:07,760 --> 00:05:11,590
authorizes who they are by putting their
information into a system, and then

96
00:05:11,590 --> 00:05:16,750
accesses that information provided they
have the right credential after the fact.

97
00:05:16,750 --> 00:05:18,890
>> Yeah and that username and
password model,

98
00:05:18,890 --> 00:05:20,900
I know it's been breaking
down in recent years.

99
00:05:20,900 --> 00:05:23,790
It really should have broken
down a long time ago.

100
00:05:23,790 --> 00:05:26,960
We are seeing all sorts from tokens and
certificates and so

101
00:05:26,960 --> 00:05:29,780
own, but there use is all the same.

102
00:05:29,780 --> 00:05:33,000
We're using them so that we verify
somebody is who they say they are, and

103
00:05:33,000 --> 00:05:36,570
then providing them the access
that's accorded to them.

104
00:05:36,570 --> 00:05:42,580
And that all kind of falls under,
what do we call it, the security triad.

105
00:05:42,580 --> 00:05:43,570
Right the triple A.

106
00:05:43,570 --> 00:05:46,880
>> The iron triangle,
the security triad or anything like that.

107
00:05:46,880 --> 00:05:48,690
There's all different ways
of thinking about that.

108
00:05:48,690 --> 00:05:51,990
But authorization is
part of that certainly.

109
00:05:51,990 --> 00:05:55,870
But the idea is really confidentiality,
integrity, and ultimately availability.

110
00:05:55,870 --> 00:05:58,740
When we thing of EA, we think about
availability not authorization.

111
00:05:58,740 --> 00:06:02,770
But when we think about confidentiality,
keeping information secure from prying

112
00:06:02,770 --> 00:06:06,440
eyes, protecting it, not letting people
see it unless they have the ability to.

113
00:06:06,440 --> 00:06:08,820
This is where authorization comes in,

114
00:06:08,820 --> 00:06:11,550
this is where access control
starts to become important.

115
00:06:11,550 --> 00:06:12,450
We have integrity.

116
00:06:13,590 --> 00:06:17,750
Integrity is the ability to be
able to validate who you are,

117
00:06:17,750 --> 00:06:20,940
to make sure that you really
are the person that sent information or

118
00:06:20,940 --> 00:06:25,320
created information in a system, and there
is no question about the authenticity of

119
00:06:25,320 --> 00:06:28,440
that information on the origination
of that information.

120
00:06:28,440 --> 00:06:29,570
And then we have availability.

121
00:06:29,570 --> 00:06:32,820
Availability's all about making sure
information is there when people need it,

122
00:06:32,820 --> 00:06:36,250
but only referencing confidentiality
when they have the requirements in

123
00:06:36,250 --> 00:06:39,000
place to be able to prove who they are,
just be aware of that and

124
00:06:39,000 --> 00:06:40,140
make sure you're thinking of that.

125
00:06:40,140 --> 00:06:43,650
But we talked about the CIA,
Confidentiality, Integrity and

126
00:06:43,650 --> 00:06:46,780
Availability triangle
that we are looking at.

127
00:06:46,780 --> 00:06:51,000
Some of the access control challenges
that we want to be able to think about.

128
00:06:51,000 --> 00:06:54,280
Are going to be things, and
we talked about a couple of these already,

129
00:06:54,280 --> 00:06:57,240
we talked about things like a door lock,
and having a front door, and

130
00:06:57,240 --> 00:06:58,840
being able to get into a building.

131
00:06:58,840 --> 00:07:00,280
Physical access, right?

132
00:07:00,280 --> 00:07:03,400
How do people get in,
do we monitor them coming in,

133
00:07:03,400 --> 00:07:05,730
are there cameras available to you?

134
00:07:05,730 --> 00:07:06,900
Things like that.

135
00:07:06,900 --> 00:07:10,390
I think accounting is spelled with a u,
but you're close.

136
00:07:10,390 --> 00:07:11,070
>> Accointing.

137
00:07:11,070 --> 00:07:13,085
>> Accointing, as opposed to accounting.

138
00:07:13,085 --> 00:07:14,140
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> There you go.

139
00:07:14,140 --> 00:07:17,790
Are we going through and are we keeping
an eye on people as they walk around and

140
00:07:17,790 --> 00:07:20,510
doing things like that, and
there's a variety of ways to do that.

141
00:07:20,510 --> 00:07:23,180
What about things like loss of laptops or
tablets.

142
00:07:23,180 --> 00:07:26,810
We're using computers, to talk to you and
we have all sorts of infrastructure,

143
00:07:26,810 --> 00:07:28,690
mobile phones, things of that nature.

144
00:07:28,690 --> 00:07:30,970
What happens if that
information disappears?

145
00:07:30,970 --> 00:07:34,170
If somebody grabs that while you're
going through a security check point.

146
00:07:34,170 --> 00:07:35,240
Is your hard drive secure?

147
00:07:35,240 --> 00:07:36,685
Is it gonna be encrypted?

148
00:07:36,685 --> 00:07:38,985
And if so,
what kind of an encryption do you use.

149
00:07:38,985 --> 00:07:41,535
What kind of hardware and
software is being used by you and

150
00:07:41,535 --> 00:07:43,685
by others as they access your information?

151
00:07:43,685 --> 00:07:44,530
Is there malware?

152
00:07:44,530 --> 00:07:46,330
Software that may inadvertently or

153
00:07:46,330 --> 00:07:49,215
on purpose access information
without authorization.

154
00:07:49,215 --> 00:07:50,411
And is that available?

01:08:37,200 --> 01:08:42,420

01:08:42,420 --> 01:08:44,820
When we talk about RAID level five,

01:08:44,820 --> 01:08:47,790

01:08:47,790 --> 01:08:50,020
And when we talk about RAID level ten,

01:08:50,020 --> 01:08:52,540
we're talking about raid level

1404
01:08:52,540 --> 01:08:56,380
And so we see on the screen here RAID

01:08:56,380 --> 01:08:58,440

01:09:01,560 --> 01:09:04,850
And what we're doing is,

01:09:04,850 --> 01:09:09,860

00:29:15,275 --> 00:29:18,895
The algorithm itself that will produce

29

30

31
00:01:59,532 --> 00:02:02,427
So let's first highlight what digital

32

us by way of introducing the concept and
then we're going to go ahead and

33

we're going to put a little screen capture

34

We're going to walk you through what the
process of creating a digital signature

35
00:02:12,300 --> 00:02:16,240

we've been talking about, symmetric,

36
00:02:16,240 --> 00:02:18,860
asymmetric and
put the whole thing in there.

37
00:02:18,860 --> 00:02:21,578
So the idea with a digital signature
is that each user is going to

38
00:02:21,578 --> 00:02:23,080
have a public-private key pair.

39
00:02:23,080 --> 00:02:26,770
This idea of the asymmetric
solution we spoke about earlier,

40
00:02:26,770 --> 00:02:32,510
where we are talking about having
a private key that is kept by the user,

41
00:02:32,510 --> 00:02:35,250
confidential, not shared
with anybody else.

42
00:02:35,250 --> 00:02:39,430
We then also have a public key that
is gonna be made available and

43
00:02:39,430 --> 00:02:43,700
that public key is made available so that
anybody who wants to interact with and

44
00:02:43,700 --> 00:02:47,370
use this digital signature, read it,
understand it, validate identity

45
00:02:47,370 --> 00:02:51,540
through it, is gonna be able to access
it and combine the two keys together.

46
00:02:51,540 --> 00:02:55,980
As a result, then be able to achieve
the end result, which will be to validate

47
00:02:55,980 --> 00:03:01,050
the sender's identity and create integrity
and non-repudiation along the way.

48
00:03:01,050 --> 00:03:05,250
So the private key is used to sign,
the private key is used to create

49
00:03:05,250 --> 00:03:08,810
the signature, and
we say the public key is used to verify.

50
00:03:08,810 --> 00:03:11,240
We may just wanna, Mike,
as you're making notes there, and

51
00:03:11,240 --> 00:03:13,660
you did a great job of putting
that stuff just up there for

52
00:03:13,660 --> 00:03:16,830
us, you'll create the signature,
would be a great capture there.

53
00:03:16,830 --> 00:03:21,820
Then for public,
we'll be doing the verification concept,

54
00:03:21,820 --> 00:03:26,210
is what we want to take away as a key
indicator of what the public key does.

55
00:03:26,210 --> 00:03:29,460
What this effectively does when we combine
the public-private key pair together in

56
00:03:29,460 --> 00:03:33,290
the digital signature is it effectively
creates this idea that I mentioned

57
00:03:33,290 --> 00:03:34,380
of non-repudiation.

58
00:03:34,380 --> 00:03:37,660
Of binding the message,
whatever the message is,

59
00:03:37,660 --> 00:03:41,810
to the user in such a way that the user
can't claim they didn't send the message.

60
00:03:41,810 --> 00:03:42,650
>> It wasn't me, I swear.

61
00:03:42,650 --> 00:03:43,260
>> Exactly, right.

62
00:03:43,260 --> 00:03:44,600
It wasn't me, I wasn't there.

63
00:03:44,600 --> 00:03:51,620
[LAUGH] We talked about this and we say
oftentimes, to use Mike as an example,

64
00:03:51,620 --> 00:03:53,730
how do we know really that Mike is
on the other end of the keyboard,

65
00:03:53,730 --> 00:03:56,470
when maybe you and
I are exchanging information.

66
00:03:56,470 --> 00:03:58,775
When you're texting with somebody,
if you're sending somebody a text or

67
00:03:58,775 --> 00:04:03,350
chatting, you connect to them, their ID,
whether it's their phone number,

68
00:04:03,350 --> 00:04:07,010
maybe it's a screen alias for chat.

69
00:04:07,010 --> 00:04:10,970
So you have a general idea,
in theory, that it's that person but

70
00:04:10,970 --> 00:04:12,220
you don't know for sure.

71
00:04:12,220 --> 00:04:14,390
>> Somebody could have their phone or
something like that

72
00:04:14,390 --> 00:04:16,270
>> Somebody could, we don't know for sure,

73
00:04:16,270 --> 00:04:20,330
there's no way to really identify
necessarily just based on the technology

74
00:04:20,330 --> 00:04:25,230
being used by itself that it really is
somebody on the other end of the phone or

75
00:04:25,230 --> 00:04:27,380
on the other end of the chat message.

76
00:04:27,380 --> 00:04:29,330
We hear cases about this all the time.

77
00:04:29,330 --> 00:04:32,400
Somebody thought it was somebody else,
realized later, it wasn't.

78
00:04:32,400 --> 00:04:35,350
There was that little sporting
incident a few months back,

79
00:04:35,350 --> 00:04:37,390
that last year we may have heard about or

80
00:04:37,390 --> 00:04:41,100
make reference to, without naming
any names or anything like that.

81
00:04:41,100 --> 00:04:46,010
But when you talk to people over the wire
or you send information over the wire,

82
00:04:46,010 --> 00:04:49,815
unless there's facial recognition
involved, face to face,

83
00:04:49,815 --> 00:04:54,445
literally me looking at you as we are now,
to truly identify face to face in

84
00:04:54,445 --> 00:04:58,775
person that the person is who we think
they are, it's very difficult to know.

85
00:04:58,775 --> 00:05:02,745
At the end of the day, we talk about
this reasonable expectation of system of

86
00:05:02,745 --> 00:05:07,035
security, reasonable expectation of
identity and identity management but

87
00:05:07,035 --> 00:05:07,985
we don't know for sure.

88
00:05:07,985 --> 00:05:12,780
This is why we come back to these ideas
of defense in depth, of building multiple

89
00:05:12,780 --> 00:05:17,500
layers of security and identity into
a system to validate who that user is.

90
00:05:17,500 --> 00:05:21,310
Remember, technology such as biometrics
that we've talked about come into play

91
00:05:21,310 --> 00:05:25,260
here, so we may be able to add
in a biometrics solution, or

92
00:05:25,260 --> 00:05:29,570
some sort of multifactor authentication
solution, where we have something,

93
00:05:29,570 --> 00:05:31,730
we know something, we are something.

94
00:05:31,730 --> 00:05:36,230
By adding one or more of those together,
we bring in so many different data

95
00:05:36,230 --> 00:05:40,200
points that it becomes very unlikely,
and we talked about the likeliness or

96
00:05:40,200 --> 00:05:43,220
unlikeliness, that
threshold that we cross.

97
00:05:43,220 --> 00:05:47,890
It tends to become much more
unlikely that somebody is indeed

98
00:05:47,890 --> 00:05:51,790
pretending to be somebody else when
we add one and then add another and

99
00:05:51,790 --> 00:05:54,030
another factor of authentication.

100
00:05:54,030 --> 00:05:58,610
So just usernames, passwords,
kind of light on the authentication.

101
00:05:58,610 --> 00:06:00,650
Maybe okay for average things but

102
00:06:00,650 --> 00:06:03,618
probably a determined attacker's
going to get past that pretty quick.

103
00:06:03,618 --> 00:06:04,250
>> Low security.
>> Yeah.

104
00:06:04,250 --> 00:06:07,549
>> Or any good five year-old who knows how
to type may get past that pretty quickly.

105
00:06:07,549 --> 00:06:09,430
>> [LAUGH] Or
people who look under the keyboard.

106
00:06:09,430 --> 00:06:11,620
>> Just flip the keyboard and
see what's there but

107
00:06:11,620 --> 00:06:16,330
when we think about this idea of adding
not just used name and password,

108
00:06:16,330 --> 00:06:22,360
something you know or something you will
know, knowledge, to something you have.

109
00:06:22,360 --> 00:06:26,670
So maybe a key fob, something like
that and then something you are,

110
00:06:26,670 --> 00:06:30,530
maybe a retina scan or an iris scan and
quick knowledge check for you, here.

111
00:06:30,530 --> 00:06:33,980
Remember, you wanna know the difference
between the retina and iris scan,

112
00:06:33,980 --> 00:06:37,500
be able to talk about those knowledgeably,
as you prepare to answer some questions.

113
00:06:37,500 --> 00:06:41,240
Reaching backwards to that episode, wanna
make sure we also know the difference

114
00:06:41,240 --> 00:06:45,570
between hand geometry and signature
dynamics, know the difference there.

115
00:06:45,570 --> 00:06:48,730
Again, forms of biometrics,
keystroke dynamics as well,

116
00:06:48,730 --> 00:06:51,730
want to make sure we understand
the differences there between those.

117
00:06:51,730 --> 00:06:54,300
If we add those things in,
it becomes a lot more valuable to us.

118
00:06:54,300 --> 00:06:57,010
The idea would be when we
provide non-repudiation,

119
00:06:57,010 --> 00:07:00,070
we want to make sure that
we are relatively secure,

120
00:07:00,070 --> 00:07:04,120
relatively sure, that the person on the
other end is indeed who they claim to be.

121
00:07:04,120 --> 00:07:07,000
This becomes important when
we are doing a lot today.

122
00:07:07,000 --> 00:07:10,960
Online banking, thinks like this where a
lot of online transactions take place, and

123
00:07:10,960 --> 00:07:14,110
we have to validate beyond a reasonable
doubt that we know who the parties are,

124
00:07:14,110 --> 00:07:16,010
and we call them trusted parties,
by the way.

125
00:07:16,010 --> 00:07:17,840
We have trusted parties.

126
00:07:17,840 --> 00:07:21,390
You can digitally sign documents
in lieu of an actual physical

127
00:07:21,390 --> 00:07:23,430
signature done in front of somebody.

128
00:07:23,430 --> 00:07:26,800
Maybe to do banking, to do bill pay,

129
00:07:26,800 --> 00:07:31,890
you can sign digital documents to attest
to things today, those kinds of things.

130
00:07:31,890 --> 00:07:35,630
We want to make sure we know how this
system works because it's coming more and

131
00:07:35,630 --> 00:07:39,309
more prevalent and so a digital signature
is effectively gonna be created.

132
00:07:40,630 --> 00:07:43,240
We're gonna take a look at the way
it's created here in just a second but

133
00:07:43,240 --> 00:07:46,280
effectively created by encrypting
a hash of the message.

134
00:07:46,280 --> 00:07:49,120
We talked about hashes in
our last episode, and so

135
00:07:49,120 --> 00:07:52,376
the hash is the concept of
creating this proof of origin.

136
00:07:52,376 --> 00:07:57,004
We take the variable data, if you remember
the formula that we had talked about,

137
00:07:57,004 --> 00:08:00,968
variable data, plus known hashing
algorithm equals fixed output.

138
00:08:00,968 --> 00:08:03,045
Not output of the data in encrypted form.

139
00:08:03,045 --> 00:08:08,780
But output of a bit stream that represents
integrity, proof of origin of that data.

140
00:08:08,780 --> 00:08:12,270
In the sense that we know that
the data as a frozen moment in time.

141
00:08:12,270 --> 00:08:15,140
A snapshot of that data at
the moment the hash is taken,

142
00:08:15,140 --> 00:08:16,355
that the data does not modify.

143
00:08:16,355 --> 00:08:19,390
>> Yeah, any change in that file is
going to invalidate that signature.

144
00:08:19,390 --> 00:08:20,160
>> It's going to change it.

145
00:08:20,160 --> 00:08:22,480
We did a nice little demo Don and
I where we actually.

We saw the difference in
the outcome of that MD5 hash.

149
00:08:32,145 --> 00:08:33,950
So that's what we're talking about.

150
00:08:33,950 --> 00:08:34,457
It was actually, it was very nice.

151
00:08:34,457 --> 00:08:38,130
It set us up for a good coffee break
after we get done with our sessions.

152
00:08:38,130 --> 00:08:41,790
So we wanna make sure that we understand
that the digital signature right?

153
00:08:41,790 --> 00:08:46,800
As I said, created by encrypting a hash
of a message with a private digital key,

154
00:08:46,800 --> 00:08:48,830
the private key of the sender.

155
00:08:48,830 --> 00:08:52,460
So we are going to hash and
then we're going to take that hash and

156
00:08:52,460 --> 00:08:54,700
we're going to encrypt the hash.

157
00:08:54,700 --> 00:08:57,670
So we're going to take the proof
of origin, proof of integrity.

158
00:08:57,670 --> 00:08:59,020
It really is Mike.

159
00:08:59,020 --> 00:09:00,670
We're going to take that proof.

160
00:09:00,670 --> 00:09:04,310
We're going to encrypt that output so
we're going to do the hash.

161
00:09:04,310 --> 00:09:07,300
We're gonna encrypt the hash,
not encrypt the data.

162
00:09:07,300 --> 00:09:09,930
Digital signatures are not
about confidentiality.

163
00:09:09,930 --> 00:09:11,230
We're not encrypting the message.

164
00:09:11,230 --> 00:09:13,100
We do that separately, by the way, right?

165
00:09:13,100 --> 00:09:14,170
But we're not doing that.

166
00:09:14,170 --> 00:09:17,560
We're encrypting the validation of
proof of origin of the message.

167
00:09:17,560 --> 00:09:21,770
And then we're gonna send that along
with the message we tend to tag it on.

168
00:09:21,770 --> 00:09:22,990
And when we do that,

169
00:09:22,990 --> 00:09:26,110
when you unencrypt the hash with
the key that will unencrypt it, and

170
00:09:26,110 --> 00:09:31,130
we'll show you a graphic of this in a
second, and you then validate the hash, we

171
00:09:31,130 --> 00:09:35,530
know that the sender has validated in our
mind if it is legitimate proof of origin.

172
00:09:35,530 --> 00:09:36,310
We know it is.
>> So

173
00:09:36,310 --> 00:09:37,580
we're really getting
two things out of that.

174
00:09:37,580 --> 00:09:40,250
We're getting integrity because we know
that message hasn't been modified.

175
00:09:40,250 --> 00:09:42,820
And we're getting
the non-repudiation because we

176
00:09:42,820 --> 00:09:44,960
can tie the identity of the creator or
sender.

177
00:09:44,960 --> 00:09:47,780
>> Proof of origin or non-repudiation
as well as integrity, correct.

178
00:09:47,780 --> 00:09:49,280
So, We're going to digitally sign.

00:09:49,280 --> 00:09:49,970
So let's take a look.

Probably a good point
to take a look at that.

Or a good place to take a look at that and

So it looks-

We never wanna ad lib when we're

195
00:10:17,892 --> 00:10:19,090
All right, so, on the left side,

196
00:10:19,090 --> 00:10:22,090
as you know in all over diagrams we have

197
00:10:22,090 --> 00:10:24,170
So, there we go, right there,

198

And, so, the sender,
let's focus on the sender side first,

00:10:35,390 --> 00:10:38,080
So we got a couple of steps we

The plain text as you can see,

Maybe it's the standard

the dog is blue, or whatever it is.

Notice that coming down directly

Down in a column like form,

00:11:04,140 --> 00:11:06,590

215
00:11:06,590 --> 00:11:09,950
we run that through our hashing solution,
use our hashing algorithm.

216
00:11:09,950 --> 00:11:14,960
If it was MD5 for instance,
we would get our 128-bit output,

217
00:11:14,960 --> 00:11:18,750
if it was a SHY1 solution
we'd get a 160-bit output.

218
00:11:18,750 --> 00:11:20,110
And so we will do our hash.

219
00:11:20,110 --> 00:11:22,300
We get what's called
the digest down there.

220
00:11:22,300 --> 00:11:26,360
The digest, which is the output of the
hash, the message digest, what we call it,

221
00:11:26,360 --> 00:11:28,500

222
00:11:28,500 --> 00:11:30,490
Notice we are encrypting that, right?

223
00:11:30,490 --> 00:11:33,200
So we're taking the hash,
we're no gonna encrypt the hash.

224
00:11:33,200 --> 00:11:36,810
And notice who's key we are encrypting
